Award.AbstractNarration:
Despite the ubiquity of wave phenomena, the mathematical analysis of the dynamics of such free boundary problems still presents great challenges of significant current interest to the research community, understanding the mechanisms of singularities, wave breaking and rogue waves is of great importance to science and engineering. The PI proposes to continue her study on the evolution of water waves. The focus in this funding period is on understanding singularities as well as long time behaviors of the water wave motion. The PI will use rigorous analytical tools to tackle the problems. Through involving graduate students and post doctors, the project will provide a training ground for a younger generation of researchers.


The mathematical problem of water waves concerns the motion of the interface separating an inviscid, incompressible, irrotational fluid, under the influence of gravity, from a region of zero density in two and three space dimensions, neglecting surface tension. In prior funding periods, the PI showed that the Taylor sign condition always holds, and obtained the local well-posedness of the two and three dimensional water wave problems for arbitrary (smooth) data. And the PI showed that the nature of the nonlinearity of the water wave problems are of cubic or higher orders, and obtained the almost global well-posedness for the two dimensional and global well-posedness for the three dimensional water wave problems for small and smooth initial data. Furthermore, to understand singular behaviors in the water wave motion, the PI constructed a class of self-similar solutions for the two dimensional water wave equation in the regime where convection is in dominance. The PI proposes to continue her study of singularities as well as the long time behaviors of the water wave motion. Particular problems include the stability of the self-similar solution she constructed and the long time evolution for a broader class of initial data.
The objective is to achieve good understanding of a basic type of waves--waves with angled crests, and its role in the long time water wave motion, and to obtain better understanding of dispersion and the structure of the water wave equations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During this funding period, the PI's main focus is on the understanding of singularities in the motion of water waves. Together with her Ph.D student Rafe Kinsey, she constructed an energy functional, $E(t)$,  which allows for interfaces with angled crests, and proved an a priori estimate for the 2-dimensional water wave equation. She then further showed that the 2D water wave equation is locally well-posed in the class defined by this energy functional (that is, for any data with $E(0)$ finite, in particular, this includes data with angled crested interfaces, the water wave equation admits a unique solution in the class with $E(t)$ finite.)  In a joint work with L. Bieri, S. Miao and S. Shahshahani, the PI studied the motion of a self-gravitating incompressible fluid with free boundary. They showed that for data that is a small perturbation of size $\epsilon$ from the equilibrium, the solution exists and remains smooth on a long time interval of the order of inverse squre of $\epsilon$.

The PI directed three Ph.D dissertations during this period: Rafe Kinsey (2014), Siddhant Agrawal (2018) and Qingtang Su (2019). Kinsey studied the gravity water waves with angled crests. Agrawal extended the result of Kinsey and the PI on gravity water waves with angled crests to the capillary-gravity water waves. He showed that the solutions of the gravity water waves with angled crests are the zero surface tension limit of the corresponding solutions of the capillary-gravity water wave equation, and the capillary-gravity water wave equation is locally wellposed in a class that allows for (nearly) angled crested interfaces. Qingtang Su studied the long time behavior of the water waves with point vortices. He showed that for certain initially symmetric vortex pairs, if the motion of the water wave is also symmetric initially, then despite the interaction with the interface, the vortex pair will keep moving downward with a positive speed. For this initial configuration, Qingtang showed that for initial data of size $\epsilon$, the solution of the water wave equation with point vortices exist on a time interval of length $O(\epsilon^{-2})$, with interface remaining small and smooth. Qingtang also showed that for this symmetric vortex pair, if the initial data is sufficiently localized, then the solution exist for all time. Qingtang Su also studied the Peregrine soliton in the water wave equation. He gave a rigorous justification of the modulation approximation for the full water wave equation in a regime that includes the Peregrine soliton, and showed that Peregrine soliton-like freak wave solutions do exist for the water wave equation.

The PI and her students have given conference and seminar talks on their work. And the results have been written and submitted to or published on peer reviewed journals. The preprints are available on arxiv.org. The PI has also given lectures in summer schools which aim at graduate students and post-docs.
